text: THE GLASS MENAGERIE.
by Tennessee Williams, 1944.
SCENE 1.

The Wingfield apartment is in the rear of the building, one of those vast hive-like conglomerations of cellular living-units that flower as warty growths in overcrowded urban centres of lower-middle-class population and are symptomatic of the impulse of this largest and fundamentally enslaved section of American society to avoid fluidity and differentiation and to exist and function as one interfused mass of automatism.

The apartment faces an alley and is entered by a fire-escape, a structure whose name is a touch of accidental poetic truth, for all of these huge buildings are always burning with the slow and implacable fires of human desperation.
The fire-escape is included in the set - that is, the landing of it and steps descending from it.
The scene is memory and is therefore non-realistic.
Memory takes a lot of poetic licence.
It omits some details; others are exaggerated, according to the emotional value of the articles it touches, for memory is seated predominantly in the heart.
The interior is therefore rather dim and poetic.
At the rise of the curtain, the audience is faced with the dark, grim rear wall of the Wingfield tenement.

This building, which runs parallel to the footlights, is flanked on both sides by dark, narrow alleys which run into murky canyons of tangled clothes-lines, garbage cans, and the sinister lattice-work of neighbouring fire-escapes.
It is up and down these alleys that exterior entrances and exits are made, during the play.
At the end of Tom's opening commentary, the dark tenement wall slowly reveals (by means of a transparency) the interior of the ground floor Wingfield apartment.
Downstage is the living-room, which also serves as a sleeping-room for Laura, the sofa is unfolding to make her bed.
Upstage, centre, and divided by a wide arch or second proscenium with transparent faded portieres (or second curtain), is the dining-room.
In an old fashioned what-not in the living-room are seen scores of transparent glass animals.
A blown-up photograph of the father hangs on the wall of the living-room, facing the audience, to the left of the archway.
It is the face of a very handsome young man in a doughboy's First World War cap.
He is gallantly smiling, ineluctably smiling, as if to say 'I will be smiling forever'.
The audience hears and sees the opening scene in the dining-room through both the transparent fourth wall of the building and the transparent gauze portieres of the dining-room arch.
It is during this revealing scene that the fourth wall slowly ascends out of sight.
This transparent exterior wall is not brought down again until the very end of the play, during Tom' s final speech.
The narrator is an undisguised convention of the play.
He takes whatever licence with dramatic convention is convenient to his purpose.
TOM enters dressed as a merchant sailor from alley, stage left, and strolls across the front of the stage to the fire-escape.
There he stops and lights a cigarette.
He addresses the audience.

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: Yes, I have tricks in my pocket, I have things up my sleeve.

speaker: Tom
text: But I am the opposite of a stage magician.

speaker: Tom
text: He gives you illusion that has the appearance of truth.

speaker: Tom
text: I give you truth in the pleasant disguise of illusion.

speaker: Tom
text: To begin with, I turn back time.

speaker: Tom
text: I reverse it to that quaint period, the thirties, when the huge middle class of America was matriculating in a school for the blind.

speaker: Tom
text: Their eyes had failed them or they had failed their eyes, and so they were having their fingers pressed forcibly down on the fiery Braille alphabet of a dissolving economy.

speaker: Tom
text: In Spain there was revolution.

speaker: Tom
text: Here there was only shouting and confusion.

speaker: Tom
text: In Spain there was Guernica.

speaker: Tom
text: Here there were disturbances of labour, sometimes pretty violent, in otherwise peaceful cities such as Chicago, Cleveland, Saint Louis. . . .
This is the social background of the play.
[MUSIC]
The play is memory.
Being a memory play, it is dimly lighted, it is sentimental, it is not realistic.
In memory everything seems to happen to music.
That explains the fiddle in the wings.
I am the narrator of the play, and also a character in it.
The other characters are my mother Amanda, my sister Laura and a gentleman caller who appears in the final scenes.
He is the most realistic character in the play, being an emissary from a world of reality that we were somehow set apart from.
But since I have a poet's weakness for symbols, I am using this character also as a symbol; he is the long-delayed but always expected something that we live for.
There is a fifth character in the play who doesn't appear except in this larger-than-life-size photograph over the mantel.
This is our father who left us a long time ago.

He was a telephone man who fell in love with long distances; he gave up his job with the telephone company and skipped the light fantastic out of town... The last we heard of him was a picture postcard from Mazatlan, on the Pacific coast of Mexico, containing a message of two words - 'Hello - Good-bye!'
and no address.
I think the rest of the play will explain itself ...

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [calling]: Tom?

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: Yes, Mother.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: We can't say grace until you come to the table!

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: Coming, Mother.
[He bows slightly and withdraws, reappearing a few moments later in his place at the table.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [to her son]: Honey, don't push with your fingers.

speaker: Amanda
text: If you have to push with something, the thing to push with is a crust of bread.

speaker: Amanda
text: And chew !

speaker: Amanda
text: chew!

speaker: Amanda
text: Animals have sections in their stomachs which enable them to digest flood without mastication, but human beings are supposed to chew their food before they swallow it down.

speaker: Amanda
text: Eat food leisurely, son, and really enjoy it.

speaker: Amanda
text: A well-cooked meal has lots of delicate flavours that have to be held in the mouth for appreciation.

speaker: Amanda
text: So chew your food and give your salivary glands a chance to function !
[TOM deliberately lays his imaginary fork down and his chair back from the table.]

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: I haven't enjoyed one bite of this dinner because of your constant directions on how to eat it.

speaker: Tom
text: It's you that makes me rush through meals with your hawk-like attention to every bite I take.

speaker: Tom
text: Sickening - spoils my appetite - all this discussion of - animals' secretion - salivary glands -mastication !

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [lightly]: Temperament like a Metropolitan star !
[He rises and crosses downstage.]

speaker: Amanda
text: You're not excused from the table.

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: I'm getting a cigarette.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: You smoke too much.
[LAURA rises.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: I'll bring in the blancmangê©.
[He remains standing with his cigarette by the portieres during the following.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [rising]: No, sister, no, sister - you be the lady this time and I'll be the darkey.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: I'm already up.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Resume your seat, little sister, I want you to stay fresh and pretty for gentleman callers!

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: I'm not expecting any gentleman callers.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [crossing out to kitchenette, airily]: Sometimes they come when they are least expected!

speaker: Amanda
text: Why, I remember one Sunday afternoon in Blue Mountain -[Enters kitchenette.]

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: I know what's coming.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Yes.

speaker: Laura
text: But let her tell it.

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: Again?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: She loves to tell it.
[AMANDA returns with bowl of dessert.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: One Sunday afternoon in Blue Mountain, your mother received seventeen gentlemen callers!

speaker: Amanda
text: Why, sometimes there weren't chairs enough to accommodate them all.

speaker: Amanda
text: We had to send the nigger over to bring in folding chairs from the parish house.

speaker: Tom
text: TOM [remaining at portieres]: How did you entertain those gentleman callers?

speaker: Amanda
text: A M A N D A: I understood the art of conversation !

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: I bet you could talk.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Girls in those days knew how to talk, I can tell you.

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: Yes?
[IMAGE: AMANDA AS A GIRL ON A PORCH GREETING CALLERS.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: They knew how to entertain their gentlemen callers.

speaker: Amanda
text: It wasn't enough for a girl to be possessed of a pretty face and a graceful figure although I wasn't alighted in either respect.

speaker: Amanda
text: She also needed to have a nimble wit and a tongue to meet all occasions.

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: What did you talk about?

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Things of importance going on in the world !

speaker: Amanda
text: Never anything coarse or common or vulgar.
[She addresses Tom as though he were seated in the vacant chair at the table though he remains by portieres.
He plays this scene as though he held the book.]

speaker: Amanda
text: My callers were gentleman -all!

speaker: Amanda
text: Among my callers were some of the most prominent young planters of the Mississippi Delta - planters and sons of planters!
[Tom motions for music and a spot of light on AMANDA.
Her eyes lift, her face glows, her voice becomes rich and elegiac.
SCREEN LEGEND: 'Oê_ SONT Les NEIGES']

speaker: Amanda
text: There was young Champ Laughlin who later became vice-president of the Delta Planters Bank.

speaker: Amanda
text: Hadley Stevenson who was drowned in Moon Lake and left his widow one hundred and fifty thousand in Government bonds.

speaker: Amanda
text: There were the Cutrere brothers, Wesley and Bates.

speaker: Amanda
text: Bates was one of my bright particular beaux!

speaker: Amanda
text: He got in a quarrel with that wild Wainwright boy.

speaker: Amanda
text: They shot it out on the floor of Moon Lake Casino.

speaker: Amanda
text: Bates was shot through the stomach.

speaker: Amanda
text: Died in the ambulance on his way to Memphis.

speaker: Amanda
text: His widow was also well provided for, came into eight or ten thousand acres, that's all.

speaker: Amanda
text: She married him on the rebound - never loved her - carried my picture on him the night he died !

speaker: Amanda
text: And there was that boy that every girl in the Delta had set her cap for!

speaker: Amanda
text: That brilliant, brilliant young Fitzhugh boy from Greene County!

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: What did he leave his widow?

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: He never married !

speaker: Amanda
text: Gracious, you talk as though all of my old admirers had turned up their toes to the daisies !

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: Isn't this the first you've mentioned that still survives ?

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: That Fitzhugh boy went North and made a fortune - came to be known as the Wolf of Wall Street!

speaker: Amanda
text: He had the Midas touch, whatever he touched turned to gold!

speaker: Amanda
text: And I could have been Mrs Duncan J. Fitzhugh, mind you!

speaker: Amanda
text: But - I picked your father !

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA [rising]: Mother, let me clear the table.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: No, dear, you go in front and study your typewriter chart.

speaker: Amanda
text: Or practice your shorthand a little.

speaker: Amanda
text: Stay fresh and pretty!

speaker: Amanda
text: It's almost time for our gentlemen callers to start arriving.
[She flounces girlishly toward the kitchenette.]

speaker: Amanda
text: How many do you suppose we're going to entertain this afternoon?
[Tom throws down the paper and jumps up with a groan.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA [alone in the dining-room]: I don't believe we're going to receive any, Mother.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [reappearing, airily ] What?

speaker: Amanda
text: Not one - not one?

speaker: Amanda
text: You must be joking!
[LAURA nervously echoes her laugh.S he slips in a fugitive manner through the half-open portieres and draws them in gently behind her.
A shaft of very clear light is thrown on her face against the faded tapestry of the curtains.]
[MUSIC: 'THE GLASS MENAGERIE' UNDER FAINTLY.
Lightly.]

speaker: Amanda
text: Not one gentleman caller?

speaker: Amanda
text: It can't be true !

speaker: Amanda
text: There must be a flood, there must have been a tornado!

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: It isn't a flood, it's not a tornado, Mother.

speaker: Laura
text: I'm just not popular like you were in Blue Mountain.
... [Tom utters another groan.
LAURA glances at him with a faint, apologetic smile.
Her voice catching a little.]

speaker: Laura
text: Mother's afraid I'm going to be an old maid.

[Gradually LAURA' s figure becomes apparent and the screen goes out.
The music subsides.
LAURA is seated in the delicate ivory chair at the small claw-foot table.
She wears a dress of soft violet material for a kimono - her hair tied back from her forehead with a ribbon.
She is washing and polishing her collection of glass.
AMANDA appears on the fire-escape steps.
At the sound of her ascent, LAURA catches her breath, thrusts the bowl of ornaments away and seats herself stiffly before the diagram of the typewriter keyboard as though it held her spellbound.
Something has happened to AMANDA.
It is written in her face as she climbs to the landing: a look that is grim and hopeless and a little absurd.
She has on one of those cheap or imitation velvety-looking cloth coats with imitation fur collar.
Her hat is five or six years old, one of those dreadful cloche hats that were worn in the late twenties and she is eloping an enormous black patent-leather pocketbook with nickel clasps and initials.
This is her full-dress outfit, the one she usually wears to the D.A.R.
Before entering she looks through the door.
She purses her lips, opens her eyes very wide, rolls them upward, and shakes her head.
Then she slowly lets herself in the door.
Seeing her mother's expression LAURA touches her lips with a nervous gesture.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Hello, Mother, I was - [She makes a nervous gesture toward the chart on the Wall.
AMANDA leans against the shut door and stares at LAURA with a martyred look.]

speaker: Amanda
text: A M A N D A: Deception ?
Deception ?
[She slowly removes her hat and gloves, continuing the sweet suffering stare.
She lets the hat and gloves fall on the floor - a bit of acting.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA [shakily]: How was the DAR meeting?
[AMANDA slowly opens her purse and removes a dainty white handkerchief which she shakes out delicately and delicately touches to her lips and nostrils.]
Didn't you go to the DAR meeting, Mother?

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [faintly, almost inaudibly]: - No.
[Then more forcibly.]
I did not have the strength - to go to the DAR.
In fact, I did not have the courage!
I wanted to find a hole in the ground and hide myself in it for ever !
[She crosses slowly to the wall and removes the diagram of the typewriter keyboard.
She holds it in front of her for a second, staring at it sweetly and sorrowfully - then bites her lips and tears it into two pieces.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA [faintly]: Why did you do that, Mother?
[AMANDA repeats the same procedure with the chart of the Gregg alphabet.]
Why are you ??

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Why?
Why?
How old are you, Laura?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Mother, you know my age.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: I thought that you were an adult; it seems that I was mistaken.
[She crosses slowly to the sofa and sinks down and stares at LAURA.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Please don't stare at me, Mother.
[AMANDA closes her eyes and lowers her head.
Count ten.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: What are we going to do, what is going to become of us, what is the future?
[Count ten.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Has something happened, Mother?
[AMANDA draws a long breath and takes out the handkerchief again.
Dabbing process.]
Mother, has - something happened?

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: I'll be all right in a minute, I'm just bewildered [Count five] by life.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Mother, I wish that you would tell me what's happened!

speaker: Amanda
text: A M A N D A: As you know, I was supposed to be inducted into my office at the D.A.R. this afternoon.
[IMAGE: A SWARM OF TYPEWRITERS.]

speaker: Amanda
text: But I stopped off at Rubicam's business college to speak to your teachers about your having a cold and ask them what progress they thought you were making down there.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Oh....

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: I went to the typing instructor and introduced myself as your mother.

speaker: Amanda
text: She didn't know who you were.

speaker: Amanda
text: Wingfield, she said.

speaker: Amanda
text: We don't have any such student enrolled at the school!

speaker: Amanda
text: I assured her she did, that you had been going to classes since early in January.

speaker: Amanda
text: I wonder,' she said, 'if you could be talking about that terribly shy little girl who dropped out of school after only a few days' attendance?'

speaker: Amanda
text: 'No,' I said, 'Laura, my daughter, has been going to school every day for the past six weeks !'

speaker: Amanda
text: 'Excuse me,' she said.

speaker: Amanda
text: She took the attendance book out and there was your name, unmistakably printed, and all the dates you were absent until they decided that you had dropped out of school.

speaker: Amanda
text: I still said, 'No, there must have been some mistake I There must have been some mix-up in the records !'

speaker: Amanda
text: And she said, 'No - I remember her perfectly now.

speaker: Amanda
text: Her hands shook so that she couldn't hit the right keys !

speaker: Amanda
text: The first time we gave a speed-test, she broke down completely - was sick at the stomach and almost had to be carried into the wash-room!

speaker: Amanda
text: After that morning she never showed up any more.

speaker: Amanda
text: We phoned the house but never got any answer' -while I was working at Famous and Barr, I suppose, demonstrating those - Oh!

speaker: Amanda
text: I felt so weak I could barely keep on my feet !

speaker: Amanda
text: I had to sit down while they got me a glass of water !

speaker: Amanda
text: Fifty dollars' tuition, all of our plans - my hopes and ambition for you - just gone up the spout, just gone up the spout like that.
[LAURA draws a long breath and gets awkwardly to her feet She crosses to the victrola and winds it up.]

speaker: Amanda
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Oh I [She releases the handle and returns to her seat.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Laura, where have you been going when you've gone on pretending that you were going to business college ?

speaker: Laura
text: L A U RA: I've just been going out walking.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: That's not true.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: It is.

speaker: Laura
text: I just went walking.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Walking?

speaker: Amanda
text: Walking?

speaker: Amanda
text: In winter?

speaker: Amanda
text: Deliberately courting pneumonia in that light coat?

speaker: Amanda
text: Where did you walk to, Laura?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: All sorts of places - mostly in the park.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Even after you'd started catching that cold?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: It was the lesser of two evils, Mother.
[IMAGE: WINTER SCENE IN PARK.]

speaker: Laura
text: I couldn't go back up.

speaker: Laura
text: I threw up -on the floor !

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: From half past seven till after five every day you mean to tell me you walked around in the park, because you wanted to make me think that you were still going to Rubicam's Business College?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: It wasn't as bad as it sounds.

speaker: Laura
text: I went inside places to get warmed up.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Inside where?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: I went in the art museum and the bird-houses at the Zoo.

speaker: Laura
text: I visited the penguins every day!

speaker: Laura
text: Sometimes I did without lunch and went to the movies.

speaker: Laura
text: Lately I've been spending most of my afternoons in the jewel-box, that big glass-house where they raise the tropical flowers.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: You did all this to deceive me, just for deception?
[LAURA looks down.]

speaker: Amanda
text: Why?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Mother, when you're disappointed, you get that awful suffering look on your face, like the picture of Jesus' mother in the museum !

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Hush !

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: I couldn't face it.
[Pause.
A whisper of strings.
LEGEND: 'THE CRUST OF HUMILITY'.]

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [hopelessly fingering the huge pocketbook]: So what are we going to do the rest of our lives?

speaker: Amanda
text: Stay home and watch the parades go by?

speaker: Amanda
text: Amuse ourselves with the glass menagerie, darling?

speaker: Amanda
text: Eternally play those worn-out phonograph records your father left as a painful reminder of him?

speaker: Amanda
text: We won't have a business career - we've given that up because it gave us nervous indigestion !
[Laughs wearily.]

speaker: Amanda
text: What is there left but dependency all our lives?

speaker: Amanda
text: I know so well what becomes of unmarried women who aren't prepared to occupy a position.

speaker: Amanda
text: I've seen such pitiful cases in the South - barely tolerated spinsters living upon the grudging patronage of sister's husband or brother's wife !

speaker: Amanda
text: - stuck away in some little mousetrap of a room - encouraged by one in-law to visit another - little birdlike women without any nest - eating the crust of humility all their life !

speaker: Amanda
text: Is that the future that we've mapped out for ourselves?

speaker: Amanda
text: I swear it's the only alternative I can think of !

speaker: Amanda
text: It isn't a very pleasant alternative, is it?

speaker: Amanda
text: Of course - some girls do marry!
[LAURA twists her hands nervously.]

speaker: Amanda
text: Haven't you ever liked some boy?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Yes.

speaker: Laura
text: I liked one once.
[Rises.]

speaker: Laura
text: I came across his picture a while ago.
AMANDA [with some interest].

speaker: Amanda
text: He gave you his picture?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: No, it's in the year-book.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: [disappointed]: Oh - a high-school boy.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: Yes.

speaker: Laura
text: His name was Jim.
[LAURA lifts the heavy annual from the claw-foot table.]

speaker: Laura
text: Here he is in The Pirates of Penzance.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [absently]: The what?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: The operetta the senior class put on.

speaker: Laura
text: He had a wonderful voice and we sat across the aisle from each other Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays in the Aud.

speaker: Laura

speaker: Laura

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA [absently]: He must have had a jolly disposition.

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: He used to call me - Blue Roses.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Why did he call you such a name as that?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: When I had that attack of pleurosis - he asked me what was the matter when I came back.

speaker: Laura
text: I Said pleurosis he thought that I said Blue Roses !

speaker: Laura
text: So that's what he always called me after that.

speaker: Laura
text: Whenever he saw me, he'd holler, 'Hello, Blue Roses !

speaker: Laura
text: I didn't care for the girl that he went out with.

speaker: Laura
text: Emily Meisenbach.

speaker: Laura
text: Emily was the best-dressed girl at Soldan.

speaker: Laura
text: She never struck me, though, as being sincere. . . . It says in the Personal Section - they're engaged.

speaker: Laura
text: That's - six years ago !

speaker: Laura
text: They must be married by now.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Girls that aren't cut out for business careers usually wind up married to some nice man.
[Gets up with aspark of revival.]

speaker: Amanda
text: Sister, that's what you'll do !
[LAURA utters a startled, doubtful laugh.

speaker: Amanda
text: She reaches quickly for a piece of glass.]

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA: But, Mother.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Yes ?

speaker: Laura
text: LAURA [in a tone of frightened apology]: I'm - crippled !

text: AMANDA: Nonsense !

speaker: Amanda
text: Laura, I've told you never, never to use that word.

speaker: Amanda
text: Why, you're not crippled, you just have a little defect - hardly noticeable, even!

speaker: Amanda
text: When people have some slight disadvantage like that, they cultivate other things to make up for it - develop charm - and vivacity and - charm!

speaker: Amanda
text: That's all you have to do !
[She turns again to the photograph.]

speaker: Amanda
text: One thing your father had plenty of - was charm!

[TOM speaks from the fire-escape landing.]

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: After the fiasco at Rubicam's Business College, the idea of getting a gentleman caller for Laura began to play a more and more important part in Mother's calculations.

speaker: Tom
text: It became an obsession.

speaker: Tom
text: Like some archetype of the universal unconscious, the image of the gentleman caller haunted our small apartment.
IMAGE: YOUNG MAN AT DOOR WITH FLOWERS.]

speaker: Tom
text: An evening at home rarely passed without some allusion to this image, this spectre, this hope.

speaker: Tom
text: Even when he wasn't mentioned, his presence hung in Mother's preoccupied look and in my sister's frightened, apologetic manner - hung like a sentence passed upon the Wingfields !

speaker: Tom
text: Mother was a woman of action as well as words.

speaker: Tom
text: She began to take logical steps in the planned direction.

speaker: Tom
text: Late that winter and in the early spring - realizing that extra money would be needed to properly feather the nest and plume the bird - she conducted a vigorous campaign on the- telephone, roping in subscribers to one of those magazines for matrons called The Home-maker's Companion, the type of journal that features the serialized , sublimations of ladies of letters who think in terms of delicate cup-like breasts, slim, tapering waists, rich, creamy thighs, eyes like wood-smoke in autumn, fingers that soothe and caress like strains of music, bodies as powerful as Etruscan sculpture.

text: AMANDA: You don't know things anywhere !

speaker: Amanda
text: You live in a dream; you manufacture illusions !
[He crosses to door.]

speaker: Amanda
text: Where are you going?

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: I'm going to the movies.

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: That's right, now that you've had us make such fools of ourselves.

speaker: Amanda
text: The effort, the preparations, all the expense !

speaker: Amanda
text: The new floor lamp, the rug, the clothes for Laura !

speaker: Amanda
text: all for what?

speaker: Amanda
text: To entertain some other girl's fiancê© !

speaker: Amanda
text: Go to the movies, go !

speaker: Amanda
text: Don't think about us, a mother deserted, an unmarried sister who's crippled and has no job !

speaker: Amanda
text: Don't let anything interfere with your selfish pleasure I just go, go, go - to the movies !

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: All right, I 'will !

speaker: Tom
text: The more you shout about my selfishness to me the quicker I'll go, and I won't go to the movies !

speaker: Amanda
text: AMANDA: Go, then !

speaker: Amanda
text: Then go to the moon - you selfish dreamer !
[Tom smashes his glass on the floor.
He plunges out on the fire-escape, slamming the door .
LAURA screams -cut by door.
Dance-hall Music up.
TOM goes to the rail and grips it desperately, lifting his face in the chill white moonlight penetrating narrow abyss of the alley.
LEGEND ON SCREEN: ' AND SO GOOD-BYE...'
TOM 's closing speech is timed with the interior pantomime.
[The interior scene is played as though viewed through soundproof glass.
AMANDA appears to be making a comforting speech to LAURA who is huddled upon the sofa.
Now that we cannot hear the mother's speech, her silliness is gone and she has dignity and tragic beauty.
LAURA' s dark hair hides her face until at the end of the speech she lifts it to smile at her Mother.
AMANDA' s gestures are slow and graceful, almost dancelike as she comforts the daughter.
At the end of her speech she glances a moment at the father's picture - then withdraws through the portieres.
At the close of Tom's speech, LAURA blows out the candles, ending the play.]

speaker: Tom
text: TOM: I didn't go to the moon, I went much further - for time is the longest distance between places.

speaker: Tom
text: Not long after that I was fired for writing a poem on the lid of a shoebox.

speaker: Tom
text: I left Saint Louis.

speaker: Tom
text: I descended the step of this fire-escape for a last time and followed, from then on, in my father's footsteps, attempting to find in motion what was lost in space - I travelled around a great deal.

speaker: Tom
text: The cities swept about me like dead leaves, leaves that were brightly coloured but torn away from the branches.

speaker: Tom
text: I would have stopped, but I was pursued by something.

speaker: Tom
text: It always came upon me unawares, taking me altogether by surprise.

speaker: Tom
text: Perhaps it was a familiar bit of music.

speaker: Tom
text: Perhaps it was only a piece of transparent glass.

speaker: Tom
text: Perhaps I am walking along a street at night, in some strange city, before I have found companions.

speaker: Tom
text: I pass the lighted window of a shop where perfume is sold.

speaker: Tom
text: The window is filled with pieces of coloured glass, tiny transparent bottles in delicate colours, like bits of a shattered rainbow.

speaker: Tom
text: Then all at once my sister touches my shoulder.

speaker: Tom
text: I turn around and look into her eyes ...

speaker: Tom
text: Oh, Laura, Laura, I tried to leave you behind me, but I am more faithful than I intended to be !

speaker: Tom
text: I reach for a cigarette, I cross the street, I run into the movies or a bar, I buy a drink, I speak to the nearest stranger -anything that can blow your candles out !
[LAURA bends over the candles.]

speaker: Tom
text: - for nowadays the world is lit by lightning !

speaker: Tom
text: Blow out your candles, Laura - and so good-bye.
[She blows the candles out.]
THE SCENE DISSOLVES.
